item.title: Go Quiz, Part 1
item.author: mail@richardmillen.com (Richard Millen)
item.description: ! W O R K ~ I N ~ P R O G R E S S ! Quiz 1 What’s the best way to pass an array to a function? Show Answers 1. The runtime sends os.Signal events in a nonblocking way. If a goroutine isn’t ready to recieve the value it’s thrown away. e.g. If the user hits Ctrl+C repeatedly, the program will receive the event only when a buffer is available in the channel and all other events will be thrown away.

item.title: Go Quiz, Part 2
item.author: mail@richardmillen.com (Richard Millen)
item.description: ! W O R K ~ I N ~ P R O G R E S S ! Quiz 1 Which package provides support for synchronizing goroutines? What value is a reference type variable set to by default and what must be done before it can be used? What is a WaitGroup and how is one declared and used? What is a slice and how is one declared? How do you iterate over a slice?

item.title: Go Quiz, Part 3
item.author: mail@richardmillen.com (Richard Millen)
item.description: ! W O R K ~ I N ~ P R O G R E S S ! Quiz 1 How do you declare condition with a multi-value case? What is the name given to a reference-type variable? What type of receiver do you use for a reference type? What does a header value contain? What types are reference types in Go? Show Answers 1. switch <expression> { case <value1>, <value2>, <value3>: // do stuff.

item.title: Go Quiz, Part 4
item.author: mail@richardmillen.com (Richard Millen)
item.description: ! W O R K ~ I N ~ P R O G R E S S ! Quiz 1 How do you turn a delimited string into a slice of strings? How could you read and discard a ‘Reader’? How do you create a channel of strings? What is a tagless switch? Show Answers 1. items := strings.Split(s, sep) 2. n, err := io.

item.title: French (Advanced) Quiz, Part 2
item.author: mail@richardmillen.com (Richard Millen)
item.description: Quiz 1 Give some examples of re verbs. “To put” “To be able” “The power” “To have to” / “must” Show Answers avoir, savoir, voir, pouvoir, devoir. mettre (put money in the meter) pouvoir le pouvoir (noun) devoir function showAnswers(divId) { var x = document.getElementById(divId); if (x.style.display === 'none') { x.style.display = 'block'; } else { x.style.display = 'none'; } } Quiz 2 “The duty” “Homework” That is your duty What are the two categories of verbs?

item.title: French (Advanced) Quiz, Part 1
item.author: mail@richardmillen.com (Richard Millen)
item.description: Quiz 1 “I want it now” “I don’t want them” “Do you want it?” (short term) “Do you want it?” (long form) “Do you want it?” (with inflection) Show Answers je le veux maintenant je ne les veux pas le voulez-vous? est-ce que vous le voulez? vous le voulez? function showAnswers(divId) { var x = document.getElementById(divId); if (x.style.display === 'none') { x.

item.title: Climate Quiz
item.author: mail@richardmillen.com (Richard Millen)
item.description: A series of short quizes about Earth’s climate. Quiz 1 What happens to ice when it’s warmed? From where does Earth get almost all of it’s energy? What form does it take? How does the Earth lose energy? What is infrared radiation? What is the temperature of the Sun? Show Answers The temperature increases until it reaches 32F (the freezing point of water), then changes state (becomes liquid) and continues to warm only once it’s finished changing state.

item.title: Electricity Quiz
item.author: mail@richardmillen.com (Richard Millen)
item.description: ! W O R K ~ I N ~ P R O G R E S S ! Quiz 1 Show Answers 1. Electrical power generation as the result of some mechanical motion is generally handled by two principal components. The field exists simply to create a magnetic field, depending on the motor, this is created by either permanent magnets or electromagnets.

item.title: Lexicon Quiz
item.author: mail@richardmillen.com (Richard Millen)
item.description: ! W O R K ~ I N ~ P R O G R E S S ! Quiz 1 Isomorphic Percentil (centile) Aphorism Lurid Apace Undemonstrative Florid Umber Juggernaut Slatternly Show Answers 1. 2. Often used in the reporting of scores from norm-referenced tests. For example, if a score is in the 86th percentile, it is higher than 86% of the other scores. The 25th percentile is also known as the first quartile (Q1),

item.title: ZeroMQ Quiz, Part 3
item.author: mail@richardmillen.com (Richard Millen)
item.description: ! W O R K ~ I N ~ P R O G R E S S ! This page contains questions & answers based on the ZeroMQ Guide written by Pieter Hintjens. Quiz 1 What aspects of control vs data flow when designing a protocol? What aspect of messaging is important when talking about performance? What aspect of messaging is affected by ‘the cost of serialisation’? What are some examples of simple self-describing structured encodings?

item.title: ZeroMQ Quiz, Part 2
item.author: mail@richardmillen.com (Richard Millen)
item.description: ! W O R K ~ I N ~ P R O G R E S S ! This page contains questions & answers based on the ZeroMQ Guide written by Pieter Hintjens. Quiz 1 Why not use ROUTER instead of PAIR sockets? Why use PAIR sockets rather than PUB / SUB sockets? Show Answers 1. ”> ROUTER wraps your message in an ““envelope”“, meaning a zero-size signal message turns into a multipart message.

item.title: ZeroMQ Quiz, Part 1
item.author: mail@richardmillen.com (Richard Millen)
item.description: ! W O R K ~ I N ~ P R O G R E S S ! This page contains questions & answers based on the ZeroMQ Guide written by Pieter Hintjens. Quiz 1 Give an example of load balancing. Give an example of fair queuing. What is the slow joiner problem? What must you do when you use a SUB socket? What happens if you don’t set any subscriptions on a SUB socket?

item.title: TDD Quiz
item.author: mail@richardmillen.com (Richard Millen)
item.description: ! W O R K ~ I N ~ P R O G R E S S ! Quiz 1 Show Answers 1. Outside of perhaps explaining a “why,” if you need a comment to explain your test, it stinks. 2. Test-drive new behavior into your system in quite small increments. 3. Test Behavior, Not Methods 4. Each test should represent the smallest meaningful increment you can think of.

item.title: C# Quiz
item.author: mail@richardmillen.com (Richard Millen)
item.description: Quiz 1 What are the differences between structs and classes? What is the best way to implement a thread-safe singleton? How does the ProgId attribute affect COM interop class registration? When and how is a finalizer invoked? What is a static constructor? Show Answers 1. Unlike in C++, the default access level for both is private. Their memory allocation models are different. A struct is a value type and its instances are created on the stack.

item.title: Unit Testing Quiz
item.author: mail@richardmillen.com (Richard Millen)
item.description: ! W O R K ~ I N ~ P R O G R E S S ! Quiz 1 Show Answers 1. ”> If you find yourself seeking esoteric mock tool features frequently, stop and take a look at your design. > Are you testing a method that’s doing too much? > Can you restructure your design in a manner so that you don’t need such complex mocking?

item.title: CentOS Quiz
item.author: mail@richardmillen.com (Richard Millen)
item.description: Below are some short quizes about the CentOS operation system. Quiz 1 Which configuration file does the OpenSSH daemon use? What command is used to start the OpenSSH service? What command is used to stop the OpenSSH service? If SSH is used, which insecure services should be disabled? What is the default system-wide SSH client configuration file? How may it be overriden? Show Answers 1. /etc/ssh/sshd_config

item.title: Microservices Quiz, Part 2

item.description: ! W O R K ~ I N ~ P R O G R E S S ! Quiz 1 What are immutable servers? if we have some configuration for our service that does change from one environment to another, how should we handle this as part of our deployment process? What are some of the downsides of running more than one service on a single host?

item.title: C++ Quiz, Part 3
item.author: mail@richardmillen.com (Richard Millen)
item.description: ! W O R K ~ I N ~ P R O G R E S S ! Quiz 1 How might you store and retrieve character code mappings using strings? How many associative containers are provided in the standard library? What is an associative array? What is an associative container? What is a hash? Show Answers 1. std::string codes[128]; // ... codes['a'] = mapped_value; codes['b'] = mapped_value; codes['c'] = mapped_value; // .

item.title: C++ Quiz, Part 2
item.author: mail@richardmillen.com (Richard Millen)
item.description: ! W O R K ~ I N ~ P R O G R E S S ! Quiz 1 What is an lvalue? What is an rvalue? What is order of evaluation? What is precedence? What is short-circuit evaluation? Show Answers 1. An expression that yields an object or function. A nonconst lvalue that denotes an object may be the left-hand operand of assignment.

item.title: C++ Quiz, Part 1
item.author: mail@richardmillen.com (Richard Millen)
item.description: ! W O R K ~ I N ~ P R O G R E S S ! Quiz 1 Explain why you might want to define your own type-specific swap function? Show Answers 1. 2. Valuelike copy-assignment operator. It is crucially important that the left-hand operand is destroyed and the right-hand operand is copied in a sequence that is correct even if an object is assigned to itself.

item.title: Docker Quiz
item.author: mail@richardmillen.com (Richard Millen)
item.description: Quiz 1 How do you run a container with interactive shell access? How do you commit changes to a new Docker image instance? How can you view the container id from an interactive shell? How do you list the docker images on your machine? How do you view active containers? Show Answers 1. docker run -it image-name 2. docker commit -m "<commit message...>" -a "<author.

item.title: Bio
item.author: mail@richardmillen.com (Richard Millen)
item.description: I am a technologist, writer, musician and family man who has spent more than 15 years building software systems. I believe in building software that accurately solves real problems. I’ve built Android apps, Websites, distributed messaging systems, desktop applications and an arduino-based product prototype. Although I do venture into web and mobile development, I spend most of my time and energy building desktop and backend systems in languages like Go, C++, C#, Python etc.
